entry.title: INSIDE DOUGLAS COUNTY 6.3.25
entry.summary: A two-part program with Ashley Cluver of Umpqua Valley Arts and Oregon House Republican Leader Christine Drazan live from Salem.

entry.title: Wind-Driven Grass Fire Burns Over 6 Acres Northwest of Roseburg
entry.summary: A wind-driven grass fire northwest of Roseburg burned 6.5 acres Monday afternoon. Crews from multiple agencies stopped the fire’s spread. Officials urge residents to take precautions when using powered equipment near dry vegetation as fire season approaches.

Battalion Chief Ryan Felker of Central Douglas Fire & Rescue said crews responded to the fire at approximately 1:45 p.m. in the 5000 block of Garden Valley Road. entry.title: MORNING CONVERSATION 6.3.25
entry.summary: Julie Denney of the Oregon Department of Transportation talks about Tuesday’s In-Person Community Open House at the Roseburg Public Library to take input on the Exit 124/125 Interchange Management Plan and Garden Valley Corridor Plan.

entry.title: UACT brings laughs and chaos to the stage
entry.summary: Usually, the cast and crew of a stage play try as much as possible to hide the behind-the-scenes work that happens during a performance. In the Umpqua Actors Community Theatre’s new production, everyone is going for the exact opposite effect.

entry.title: Summer of construction: A look at ongoing major projects in Douglas County
entry.summary: The return of warm weather to Douglas County brings lots of opportunities; a chance to get outdoors, visit annual festivals and to move forward with major construction projects.

entry.title: Riddle Activity Center secures building permit
entry.summary: RIDDLE — Johnny Mcelroy envisions the Riddle Activity Center as a “mental health hub” for the city. For the founder of Neighborhood Behavioral Health, one organization moving into the center following its launch, the space can’t get here fast enough.

entry.title: A wool-derful weekend awaits sheep handlers of Douglas County
entry.summary: The 2025 Mike McWilliams Memorial Shearing Contest will feature one additional caveat: the winner will walk away with a berth on the next U.S. National Team.

entry.title: DELEGATION: OVER $80 MILLION TO SUPPORT ODOT’S DISASTER RECOVERY EFFORTS
entry.summary: June 3, 2025 7:00 a.m. On Monday, Oregon’s U.S. Senators Jeff Merkley and Ron Wyden, along the state’s five Democratic House members announced that the Oregon Department of Transportation is receiving over $83 million for work it completed to repair roads and other critical infrastructure that were deeply damaged during natural disasters. A joint release...

entry.title: Crash Claims Life of 19-Year-Old Motorcyclist in Roseburg
entry.summary: A crash on NW Stewart Parkway Saturday night claimed the life of 19-year-old motorcyclist Zevin Alvarez. Roseburg Police say the driver of a car admitted to running a red light. The investigation remains ongoing.

entry.title: Attic Fire Displaces Family in Green on Monday Afternoon
entry.summary: A fire in the attic of a Green home Monday displaced several adults, children, and pets. Crews from CDF&R and partner agencies contained the fire in 20 minutes. The likely cause was a discarded cigarette. The American Red Cross is assisting the displaced family.

entry.title: Book Review: Fans First: Change the Game, Break the Rules & Create an Unforgettable Experience by Jesse Cole
entry.summary: In Fans First, Jesse Cole—founder of the Savannah Bananas baseball team and its signature yellow tuxedo—delivers more than a book; he delivers a manifesto on reimagining customer experience. With unfiltered enthusiasm and a flair for the unconventional, Cole offers a powerful reminder that fan obsession—not industry norms—should drive business strategy. entry.title: Observatory cancels summer public programs
entry.summary: WINCHESTER — Umpqua Community College's Paul Morgan Observatory cancelled summer public program events due to construction at the college's track. The Moon Watch event on June 7 and the public night on June 20 are both cancelled.

entry.title: SOU faculty members take lead role in open textbook project
entry.summary: (Ashland, Ore.) — Open Oregon Educational Resources, a statewide initiative that promotes textbook affordability for students at Oregon colleges and universities, is releasing four new open textbooks whose authors include four Southern Oregon University faculty members and a student in the Criminology and Criminal Justice program. “Our goal with these projects is to provide rigorous… The post SOU faculty members take lead role in open textbook project appeared first on Southern Oregon Business Journal.

entry.title: The Agriculture Industry in Southern Oregon: A Risk Management Perspective
entry.summary: By Paul Quandt Southern Oregon’s agriculture sector, renowned for its diverse crops such as wine grapes, pears and specialty produce, is facing a complex landscape during 2025. entry.title: Bend MSA Adds Two Counties
entry.summary: by David Cooke and Nicole Ramos, State of Oregon Employment Department March 11, 2025 The Bend Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA) is now three counties: Crook County, Deschutes County, and Jefferson County. Previously the Bend-Redmond MSA included only one county: Deschutes County. Also, the old name for the MSA was “Bend-Redmond, OR MSA”. The title was shortened based on… The post Bend MSA Adds Two Counties appeared first on Southern Oregon Business Journal.

entry.summary: by Henry Fields, Workforce Analyst, Oregon Employment Department May 20, 2025 Although most people work in full-time jobs, around 23% of employed Oregonians regularly worked part-time schedules in 2024. People work part time for a variety of reasons. entry.title: ROSEBURG HAS HOTTEST DAY OF THE YEAR ON FRIDAY
